author: ghost
body:
Often I use utilities like `unixtodos.exe` and `dostounix.exe` to fix the line endings of documents. It would be super helpful if PowerShell team consider it as a useful utility and provide it OOTB.

One solution is: https://stackoverflow.com/a/19128003 but it "almost" works as "mike z" mentioned.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
`ConvertTo-EOL -Unix`
`ConvertTo-EOL -Windows`

Also we can consider adding -EOLUnix/-EOLWindows parameters in Get-Content/Set-Content/Out-File
Previously we discussed Encoding cmdlets - we could add the parameters in the cmdlets.

@mklement0 It seems you had suggestions about this?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@kasper3: The SO answer you link to is an unfortunate train wreck (as of this writing) that I'm struggling to have fixed (it's not up to me).
I've just written up a [new answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/48919146/45375) that shows that it _can_ be done in PSv5+, but with _limitations_.

It is these limitations that suggest that creating a dedicated cmdlet is indeed a good idea.

We need to be mindful of:

* The fact that the value of such a cmdlet would be in intelligently updating the input file _in place_ so as to preserve its encoding:
   * without needing to read the entire input file into memory
   * if a temporary file is involved, ensuring that the rewritten file has all the attributes of the original (creation timestamp, permissions, metadata).

* Yet there is no precedent (that I can think of) of `ConvertTo-*` cmdlets performing _in-place file updating_. We need to think about how to convey that aspect through the naming / parameters.

@iSazonov: I've suggested adding a `-Delimiter` parameter to `Set-Content` in #3855, which is still worth implementing, but for intelligent - and performant -  in-place updating of files that is not enough.

comments.author: ghost
comments.body: @iSazonov, is there any kind of approval process or this could just be implement by anyone?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @kasper3  Right way is to create RFC in https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
In-place update can be dangerous. We could create temp file, process and replace original file and have ip-place update as option.
Also should we accept strings from pipeline and as argument?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@iSazonov: 

> We could create temp file, process and replace original file

In fact, to prevent data loss, that's the _only_  "in-place" updating we should offer (it is what I meant by "in-place", loosely).

> Also should we accept strings from pipeline and as argument?

I guess we can, though I suspect processing _files_ will be the primary focus (if we get `Set-Content -Delimiter`, you can use just that to write an array of input strings; if the input is already a multiline string, you can just use `... -replace '\r?\n', '\n'`, etc.)

Now that I think about it: `Convert` is not the right verb for the cmdlet being discussed, because `Convert-*` cmdlets output _objects_, _in memory_.

Perhaps `Set-Eol` or `Set-Newline` is better, given that the [definition of the `Set` verb includes](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms714428%28v=vs.85%29.aspx):

> Replaces data on an existing resource or creates a resource that contains some data

What would make it unusual is that in the absence of input it would update the _existing content_, so perhaps we do need an explicit switch for that; e.g.:
 
```powershell
# Convert foo.txt in place (conceptually speaking) with Unix newlines
# Prevent pipeline input in this case.
Set-Eol foo.txt -Unix -InPlace

# Write strings with specified newline to foo.txt, potentially replacing existing content
# To avoid accidental destruction of foo.txt, empty/null input should be prevented.
'one', 'two' | Set-Eol foo.txt -Windows
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: With `-replace '\r?\n', '\n'` I agree that we don't need accept strings from pipeline and as argument.  And after that we don't need `ConvertTo` and can use another verb. Now question maybe enhance Set-Content? why we need new cmdlet?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Enhancing `Set-Content` is an option, good point.

The only concern may be discoverability.

Here's what it could look like, using dedicated switches `-Lf` and `-CrLf` (though with the anticipated `-Delimiter` parameter you could (also) do ``-Delimiter "`n"`` and ``-Delimiter "`r`n"`` ):

```powershell
# Convert foo.txt in place (conceptually speaking) with Unix newlines
# * -InPlace  requires either -Lf or -CrLf
#  * When using -InPlace, no pipeline / -Inputobject input is permitted.
Set-Content foo.txt -Lf -InPlace

# Write strings with Windows newlines to foo.txt, potentially replacing existing content.
'one', 'two' | Set-Content foo.txt -CrLf
```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
While `-WindowsToUnix` and `-UnixToWindows` are reminiscent of the venerable `dos2unix` and `unix2dos` utilities, my concerns are:

* There's no need to incorporate the _source_ in the name; arguably, only the *target* EOL style matters, so it could be `-ToUnix` or `-ToWindows`

* However, neither conveys the aspect of pertaining to _newlines_ (EOLs) in the context of the `Set-Content` cmdlet whose primary purpose is not about newlines.

My sense is that the terms LF and CLRF are sufficiently established as referring to the platform-respective newline styles and as such `-Lf` and `-Crlf`  do convey that they're about newlines.

Perhaps others can weigh in. @SteveL-MSFT, any thoughts?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: I think this has been a great discussion and the different options to consider I think warrants a RFC.  Personally, I can see the EOL conversion to be part of a `Convert-File` cmdlet which can also handle encoding although we could just start with EOL first.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Thanks, @SteveL-MSFT.

I like the name `Convert-File`, because it does convey the notion of converting an existing file from one format to another (assuming that was your intent :), and combining that with re-encoding functionality makes good sense.

(I suppose it would then make it awkward to have that cmdlet also support writing _new_ content to a file with the specified encoding / newline style, but maybe we don't have to, because that's what `Set-Content -Encoding -Delimiter` could cover.)

Enough said - happy RFCing!

comments.author: jeffbi
comments.body: While I like the name, I'm a bit concerned that it would have pretty broad interpretation. What will users expect a cmdlet named Convert-File to do? Convert from, say, XML to JSON? From .doc to .docx? Or just encoding and line endings?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body: @jeffbi: Fair point; `Convert-TextFile`?

comments.author: ghost
comments.body:
@mklement0, you have much better hang on the shape of the cmdlet and arguments; would you consider opening an RFC based on the ideas shared here? :)
It would be great if performance characteristics are also kept in mind. For example, instead of reading the file (that can be huge in order of gigabytes) in memory, replace and write back the content; we can open the stream, walk through each character once, and write back. Overall complexity will remain O(1)+O(1). Maybe this kind of approach: https://stackoverflow.com/a/1971052. If it is going to run only on .NET Core 2.1+, then we have even performant APIs like System.IO.Pipeline, Span<T>, Memory<T>, System.Runtime.Intrincis to squeeze the last bit of performance. Some people compared and complained about PS performance vs. Python in this area: https://stackoverflow.com/q/9724521.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@kasper3: 

You seem to have the right knowledge regarding a _performant implementation_ of the new cmdlet, so I suggest _you_ write the RFC :)

I'm happy to give you my $0.02 regarding the cmdlet's syntax - see below - and if you later have questions, I'm happy to weigh in, but I suggest you take it from here.

Suggested syntax (simplified); I've thrown in the re-encoding functionality, but, as Steve said, that doesn't have to be there in the first round:

```none
Convert-TextFile [-Path] <string[]> [-Lf] [-CrLf] [-FromEncoding <Encoding>] [-ToEncoding <Encoding>] [-AsByteStream] 
    
Convert-TextFile [-LiteralPath] <string[]> [-Lf] [-CrLf] [-FromEncoding <Encoding>] [-ToEncoding <Encoding>] [-AsByteStream]
```

* `-Path` and `-LiteralPath` should follow the pattern of existing cmdlets such as `Get-ChildItem` (`-Path` supports wildcards, `-LiteralPath`, which can be bound via the pipeline via the `.PsPath` property, does not).

* `-Lf` and `-CrLf` are mutually exclusive, but either may be combined with any combination of `-FromEncoding` and `-ToEncoding` (see @SteveL-MSFT's comments below re alternative/supplemental use of `-LineEndings` with values named for the target platforms)

   * `-Lf` unconditionally writes Unix newlines (`\n` only)
   * `-CrLf` unconditionally writes Windows newlines (`\r\n`)
   * In both cases, _terminator_ logic is applied; i.e., the _last_ line is terminated with a newline as well.

* [Edited to address @jeffbi's comments] _Input_ line endings should be recognized automatically, in all flavors (LF-only, CRLF, CR-only (Classic Mac OS), the way `Get-Content` does. There's probably no need to support CR-only newlines on _output_.

* In addition to either `-Path` or `-LiteralPath`, at least _one_ of `-Lf`, `-CrLf`, and `-ToEncoding` must be passed.

* In the absence of `-FromEncoding`, the usual rules apply: detect the standard Unicode BOMs; default to UTF-8 in their absence.

* In the absence of `-ToEncoding`, default to whatever the effective _input_ encoding was (whether inferred from the existing content  or explicitly specified with `-FromEncoding`).

* (Conceptual) in-place updating of the input files is performed by default, EXCEPT

  * if `-AsByteStream` is specified, in which case the input files are left untouched and a _byte array_ is passed out, which can be saved to a different file - albeit only a _single_ one - using `Set-Content -AsByteArray`. Passing the bytes one by one will not perform well, though.  
Note that there's currently no way to send a raw byte stream to external programs.   

Note that decoding and encoding will hamper performance, though conceivably you could optimize the cases where no transcoding is needed and switch to byte(-tuple) processing there.

@jeffbi:

> would the cmdlet be able to recognize OS 9 style line endings (CR only)

Yes, it should, because `Get-Content` does.

iSazonov

comments.author: ghost
comments.body: Maybe without `s`, `LineTerminator`, `LineBreak` or `LineFeed`? LineFeed would have been great, but since LF stands for 'Line Feed', it might be confusion (may require disambiguation: `Carriage Return Line Feed` vs. `Line Feed`) .

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
I agree that it should be the singular form, @kasper3.

In terms of abstract names, here's what [WikiPedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline) offers:

> **_Newline_** (frequently called **_line ending_**, **_end of line_** (**_EOL_**), **_line feed_**, or **_line break_**)

But I agree that `-LineFeed` is problematic, because it is the name of a specific character, `LINE FEED (LF)` (`U+000A`).

With the help of parameter aliases, here's a way to make everyone happy:

```none
# aliases
-Newline
-LineEnding
-Eol
-LineBreak
-LineTerminator
```

`-LineTerminator`, while not a common term, and the more established `-LineEnding` have the advantage of conveying that the newlines will act as a _terminator_ (last line ending with a newline, as is required on Unix for a well-formed text file) rather than as a _separator_ (last line _not_ ending in a newline, as is common on Windows).

As for the shortcut switches `-Lf` and `-CrLf`: Again, they can _coexist_ with the verbose form; I would find them personally convenient, but if the consensus is that they're not worth it / add too much implementation complexity, I will make my peace with a less decked out bike shed :)

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:

If we want `-EncodingFrom/-EncodingTo` in the cmdlet I'd prefer more simple parameter sets - without `-Lf/-CrLf`.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this.  We cannot simply replace Cr and Cr/Lf without knowing the encoding of the file (ie, UTF-8 vs UTF-16).  Therefore, `Convert-TextFile` cannot support translating line endings without the encoding work at the same time.  As for the line ending parameters, the Committee recommends just `-LineEnding <Cr|CrLf|Windows|Unix>` and not have `-Cr -CrLf`.
